topic.title: 0net p2p games?
topic.body:
Brief search over 0net shows there are quite a few (mostly ported) singleplayer games, some even with scoring tables. But i haven't found any multiplayer games, even on proof of concept level. Is it just me (and search engines) not looking enough or does 0net actually lack any?

I can see there might be difficulties in building hard rt games on one hand and stable competitive world on the other hand. Still, might be an interesting thing to try.

topic.title: Here, but not on 0me?
topic.body:
It is well known that different people prefer different forms of organizing communication, even for the same kind of content. While we may complain and argue who's right, or even create a [new ultimate platform that will fix everything](https://xkcd.com/927/), today i'm here not for that kind of thing. Rather, i'm curious how many people read 0talk, but do not (or do rarely) read 0me?

Personally i'm glancing over both, unless there's too much of new topics/posts at the moment.

topic.title: File rename/move detection?
topic.body:
I wonder if there's such a feature in 0net. The idea is that when a file is moved/renamed with intact content, it should not be re-downloaded by everyone; of course, this is mostly important for big files. Specifically, i need this to be able to post files before i'm sure what name should they have in the end.

If there isn't such a feature (or request) already, i'm going to make a feature request myself.

**EDIT**: the [gh issue](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1318) is open and haven't received any attention; [0talk thread](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1520004466_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS) suggests this is not implemented

**EDIT2**: [HelloZeroNet commented 38 minutes ago](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1318#issuecomment-483732730)

> Not yet, but just started working on it.

topic.title: 0net sites running on non-free/libre js?
topic.body:
I'm making a blocklist for these, so if you know any, please let me know (i really don't want to publish one-site blocklist and i'm pretty sure there should be more). "Nonfree" means, of course, code not under a free/libre/open-source software license (and not in public domain). This is not always trivial to spot, so in some cases asking site owner might be required for clarification.

Sites with trivial code (oneliners and such) without license are exempted. Sites that load and use nonfree js only optionally **and** give an appropriate warning before doing so won't be on this list as well. The list is also not intended for sites with mining scripts or outright malware, there seems to be enough blocklists for those.

**update**: the list is now [here](/1NbHaHHyiXpTgSpaRW5VgpvuJsSBSSmbLG/), but still waiting for additions

17_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd.body:
You should note that apart from technical challenges (which are, of course, solveable) there is government control issue. Do you really believe that if government whitelists internet, it will look at your horizontal ZeroNet transfer and do nothing?

Some governments already forbid public wi-fi without requiring providers to identify its users; they may as well ask every wi-fi provider to store all traffic and block all encrypted and p2p connections. And, of course, sanction everybody who sets up wi-fi access point without registering with children/anti-terrorist/copyright protection registry.

Of course, it may seem to be hard to enforce. But for your idea to work, you need a lot of users joining in and then you can no longer really hide forever.

1515376361_1P7ZF1U5tMb3BKzp6jxWzz37VqGg2.body:
It really depends on how you define capitalism. If capitalism is only free market, then sure, p2p is compatible with it. But if capitalism is "rule of capital", then p2p is anti-capitalist in its nature (still can be used by capitalism, though).

As for "piracy", it mostly strengthens capitalism (even if it can sometimes ruin someone's business). Even if you are forever ideologically "pirating" and will never pay a penny, as long as you spread content and/or your opinion about content, you still help it.

So paradoxically the best way to oppose IP laws is to stop using and promoting all proprietary content and spread only free culture.

>Sooner or later, however, we will have to accept that money will soon become meaningless, and post-scarcity, technological 'socialism' is inevitable.

Not necessarily. Capitalism is good at enforcing scarcity and most people accept it happily.

>The only reason why socialism has failed in the past is because of this scarcity barrier that still exists, but is slowly beginning to thin out.

It's not the only reason. If you really want to have one reason, it'd be human stupidity. People who tried to force socialism, people who tried to stop it and people who supported either forces usually all lacked in rationality (or, sometimes, good will).

>Now I don't think artists should be forced to release everything for free

I think most people would agree artists shouldn't be forced to release anything at all. But to say "shouldn't be forced to release for free", you should first define what does that mean. Because it can be argued that the moment you give someone access to your precious bytes (for whatever price), they're free to do with it what they want.

>Money is a form of voluntary exchange, its not some evil plot to enslave people into doing what someone wants.

If it is not some evil plot (which seems to be the case), it doesn't make it only a form of voluntary exchange. If you look at history of money, you will notice that apart from being a form of voluntary exchange, it is sometimes a form of involuntary exchange because you're forbidden to use other forms. Then it is used for tracking and taxation (which is in no way voluntary).

But lets for the sake of argument assume some ideal money, e.g. an ideal cryptocurrency that is considered to be absolutely safe, anonymous and decentralized. Now it seems that we finally have the voluntary exchange and nothing else, right? Again, not necessarily. It now depends on how do you define "voluntary".

If you have enough money, well, you spend them however you like (even if you're influenced by manipulative marketing, but that's another topic). But if you barely have any money to feed yourself and your family? Do you then voluntary spend your last penny on cheap macaroni or do you spend it because the other choice is starvation? Depends on definition.

But if you consider buying food out of fear to starve voluntary, then what about giving away your money out of fear to have your throat cut?

>(always has been true with Radio, now with YouTube, where you can play as much music as you want, just not all songs ever recorded).

I kinda doubt that's true. I haven't been checking UAs of all the services all the time, but usually you're only allowed to "consume the content in private as long as it's available on the site".

1515603525_1AJ7ycQQz14iRht5CYH4KmvE549VZ.body: It's possible to use 0net through tor already. (i can't definitely tell whether it's enough or not, but still)

> [lucifersneighbor](#comment_6_16GUvkoVwUVDDUsbPWkkSxpq2ikmK9bd6E): The idea of crypto-anarchism is simple though: You don't have to convice anyone that your math is right if it is right. You just win. Game over.

And then the government politely asks you to stop using cryptography without a license and cuts you off the internet if you refuse (i'm just imagining some very polite gov; some might simply put you into jail for aiding terrorism, pedophiles and drug dealers). And forbids mesh nets, and tracks you offline.

And what do you think is the reason some governments don't do that?..

>If that is actually what is happening where you live

No, not yet ;) Though some things are already happening in many countries (running tor exit nodes is dangerous for a long time already, refusing to give up encryption keys can lead to conviction, anonymous internet connections are banned in one way or another, surveillance cameras are being put everywhere and *can* be aided by people's smartphones, etc etc)

>The reason is that, in a real democracy, your fellow men would on avarage need to actually think that cryptography is bad for it to be illegalized

Yeah, but if they are being persuaded only from one side (gov), they are very likely to end up being convinced that strong cryptos are bad. I can easily imagine that most of currently popular crypto can eventually get broken due to increased computing power and anything beyond that is considered "aiding terrorism", because sure enough they'll find real terrorists who use it.

>until you actually end up in a world where having a encrypted conversation with remote peers would be actually illegal

Perhaps there will always be a way to chat with someone you know in encrypted way. There are various methods to evade most content filtering systems on individual basis. But if you want full-featured encrypted network, it's very hard to stay unnoticed (e.g. see tor in china).

>Basically, the current Russian culture is that in Russia
>NOBODY OWNS ANYTHING, except the Czar.

That's a comfortable cliche that can be used to explain everything, but there is also a counter-cliche that "the czar is a myth". The kind of myth (so the theory goes) that is beneficial to the government as a whole. Like, an almost literal message of inner propaganda says "the tsar is good, it's the boyars who are bad".

But it is also nothing more than a model, possibly useful in some cases and useless in others.

It seems that almost everyone (of those who speak up, that is) has their perfect theory and believe in it because it is smarter than some alternative. But if one theory is wrong, it doesn't make the other automatically right. And when you don't understand something, it's better to admit it than simply assume that whatever you see as best available explanation is actually true.

1517219248_13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiK.body:
What i had in mind was something slow and long-term (possibly with high degree of social element to make it more appealing) where as wellan said game logic has clear deterministic rules and can be processed equally on each node. Basically, you make at most a few "moves" a day and to calculate current game state current time and all recorded moves are taken into account. Even some random element could be implemented, via third-party blockchain.

I'm still not sure whether it'll be easy to fully eliminate cheating (e.g. rewriting old moves) without writing them on blockchain or something like that. I haven't seen 0frame API that could prevent deleting 'owned' files.

Though in any case, such a system could be made to work with honorable players and whitelisting.
I think the best solution would be to add possibility for client to ignore any deletion or modifications of certain files to 0net itself. Can be called "write-only" files or something.

>Yes, but dynamic content is the nature of ZeroNet, preventing deletion or modification is harder than it seems, because the only guarantee you have is that all content is signed, but you can't really constraint the content itself. 

Simply forbid overriding a file. If original node deletes or modifies it, every node that have original should refuse such change. Deleted files will still get propagated and two versions of the same file will be proof of original node being malicious.

This scheme will lead to more files being used, though.

>96% blocks valid

Looks like i've already broken something?..

> [obiwanzanobi](#comment_87_1LUy9iAxeWsj1DP5L8V17Yb2vo87FucjgD): problem is you need to change files to play a game (eg update the amount of in-game currency, level, gear, etc)

Well, blockchain doesn't need to modify files to change amount of currency, and so can we ^_^

I should've probably just coded prototype, but since i didn't i'll clarify.

In a simple case, all game state is defined by `users/<userid>/actions/<actionid>.json` files. To get current game state, engine takes in account all recorded actions and applies them from the start to end (in order of timestamps, so of course there might be syncing issues, but that's another matter).

More complex case would include some kind of key points to avoid file bloat.

1519391319_17EoDsZVVgqN1WCV6uPjtiW8Wjmhw.body:
I think if you limit 0net browser to localhost, the only way to report your fingerprints through js (except for possible vulnerabilities) would be to write them down into files and distribute over 0net. This is of course possible, but it's also relatively easy to notice if you would setup some kind of traffic inspector for 0net. Luckily most zites have fairly simple .json data schemes so if you see something suspicious, you can stop using that zite.

However, it'd be much better if there would be (optional) history for 0net files so that if someone enabled surveillance feature on their zite for a short period of time it would still not go unnoticed.

It would also be nice if there would be a commonly accepted standard of marking js source and data exchange model.

> [helium](#comment_265_1Pv5CdXMDJm5k5iAp4SVbutnMg2ue8e58p): The way I understand, even if data structures, structured text(XML, JSON, YAML, etc.) were given some "grammar" [...]

Well, it depends on how far are you willing to restrict web apps. For most typical 0net usecases, important data sent to network by js is user-inputted text and timestamps. I can't imagine fully reliable way to control that text written to 0net file is equal to user-inputted text (although it is possible to detect any non-printable characters and inject simple random changes in order to make it even harder to come up with working scheme), but checking timestamp mongering is relatively easy as last few digits can be safely rewritten in all non-rt tasks where only user actions lead to data being sent.

Of course, even more protection can be implemented by checking data changes before signing them. There might be valid usecases which cannot be dealt with this way, but if you care about privacy you can stop using those web apps or at the very least sandbox them more strictly (depends on your reasons to stay anonymous).

This probably won't guarantee that no bits of fingerprinting ever slip past your radar. But it can lower transmission rate and depending on goals of surveillance and your goals, can make such leaks impractical to use (in other words, have very low success probability).

As for marking js source url, it serves two purposes. First, one can automatically check whether the script on page matches source code; then, one can analyze source code for hidden features and possible vulnerabilities.

About tor DNS leaks: it seems that unfortunately tor devs do not make it especially easy to find relevant information, but there seems to be options to mitigate dns leaks: [transparent proxy](https://trac.torproject.org/projects/tor/wiki/doc/TransparentProxy), [socks proxy faq entry](https://www.torproject.org/docs/faq.html.en#WarningsAboutSOCKSandDNSInformationLeaks).

1519995278_1PGFKCfMSL1QdudndfYCo4mGM8E8X.body:
The problem with consensus is that one person is enough to break it. Thus for consensus to be effective, there should be basic trust among peers: everyone should work towards common goal and trust that others attempt this as well. Thus pure consensus is not going to work reliably in a society known to have bad actors.

If you carefully select peers to make sure they are e.g. 99.9% reliable, then "almost-consensus" (e.g. consider 99% of vote to make decision) might work. But i don't think it's possible to attach 99.9% reliability online.

Another possible approach is to make sure that reasonable people with good will would agree with you. If you choose that, i recommend starting with ethical system and rationality basis. Those who would agree with you on that are likely to be able to discuss meaningfully the rest of details.

And then there's a theoretical technical approach: build a system where you attach different levels of trust to individual contributions, in which every person with high rationality and ethical standards will see contributions with similar people as more trustworthy. But it is still going to need protection from abuse in form of peers rationality.

>I have to point that the consensus system would only be necessary for the document-creation process

You can't get consensus of random people and be sure it's any better than just you creating your document.

I think the reasonable way to do this (if you don't want to simply write something yourself and see if it sticks) is to start writing the document, post it continuously and respond to reasonable critique (if you don't postulate your ability to think rationally, all else would be in vain).

Possible caveats:

- there are some smart people who would not respond to this in the beginning or might stop caring later because they would conclude that you started such a project before properly educating yourself (i'm saying this as someone who doesn't have a high formal education and generally considering themselves pretty uneducated, but noticing that average net users are even much less educated); thus you risk building community of mediocre

- people who will be attracted to your project might be biased towards certain ideas and if that happens, it might lead to a sort of sectarianism, where peers would support the established ideas

- even without concrete ideas bias, participants are likely to suffer [bias blind spot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bias_blind_spot), which may eventually lead to community splitting/breaking until only like-minded people stay around you

While i don't want to indulge in discussions about "living off the grid" thing, i can't pass without making a couple notes on those C-words.

In short: it's best to avoid terms whose history you don't know, and in this case you seem to be utterly unaware of it.

In more details:

Both words seems to be popularized by Karl Marx, but *were used before him*. As far as i understand it (and i encourage you not to take my word for it), "capitalism" is/was usually used to describe some existing social system. "Communism" on the other hand is/was usually used to describe a non-yet-existent ideal society.

Just from that, we can see that saying "We've seen the extreme of one or both" is not a universally correct statement (it is correct with some substitutions, but incorrect with others, *no less valid* ones).

Now lets consider words "capitalis**t**" and "communis**t**" (as noun-adjectives, referring to persons here; not just adjective describing certain aspects of a system), which seem to be usually implied when people talk about these -isms. First thing that you notice (which follows from aforementioned categorical distinction between "capitalism" and "communism" words) is that "capitalist" might mean "a high-ranking rich individual in capitalistic system" or "a proponent of capitalistic ideology", while "communist" usually refers only to proponents of ideology because there's no communist society and *there would be no high-ranking individuals if it would exist*.

Self-proclaimed proponents of certain ideology, however, might say completely different things and even go at war with one another, which is why at best a correct statement about "communists" might be something like "*most self-proclaimed communists i've met are* scum or stupid". Same goes for capitalism proponents. As for "capitalists" as high-ranking individuals, this is a bit more objective category, but even then all you can definitely say would be statistical. For example, "capitalistic system tends to work in a way that scum gets privileged" or "capitalistic system tends to make people who succeed in it morally bad", etc.

I hope that's enough to make you consider that many -isms have way too much meanings and using them in some "mainstream way" leads to supporting such mainstream ideology and can be source of miscommunication, leading to useless arguments, holywars and even irl violence.

1520480628_19k3r2zgWTUszFvHSBBrxDWzEt83V.body:
>if a group is being threatened or oppressed, I do believe they have a right to voluntarily fight for their freedom/defense.

This seems to be quite a common position, but it also have caveats. What would you consider to be a group? One could say that humanity is threatened and oppressed (which is certainly not easy to deny) and start a war against oppressors. Then again, what exactly is "threatened" and "oppressed"?

***

I think that while it might be true that ultimately no war is justified (what is war, again?), we should still differentiate between more and less justified wars.

For example, no vengeance killing is ultimately justified. Consider the act of killing someone who just killed someone else. The only way to attach *absolute* moral value to it is to call it unacceptable. Which means that you also are unjustified in killing them. And if you attach *relative* moral value to the act and still kill them, then you should expect others being as *relatively* justified as you were.

Basically, everyone who takes up arms should be prepared to die *by someone acting ethically in their understanding of situation*.

Does that mean that no one should take up arms? That's debatable. If you're being *directly* threatened to be killed and didn't kill anyone yet, the case for killing in self-defence seems to be quite strong.

The main point is of course that anything you do is your responsibility. Joining armed forces and making an oath is your responsibility. Following orders is your responsibility. Giving orders is your responsibility.

Any authority system wants to make an illusion of taking away freedom and thus responsibility so that everyone obeys the orders and the system works.

> [krixano](#comment_379_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): I know that "merger" doesn't translate well into some languages (by what some of the translators have said). What do you think I should do about this? Should I just keep the word in English? I don't fluently speak any other languages besides English, so I want to get the translations as understandable and good as possible.

The global problem with localization (and especially special term translations) is that there are at least two categories of people using it: those who know or are learning english on one hand and those who do not and will not on the other. For those who communicate with the global community (or have to use some other unlocalized software) it is of course easier when the terms are minimally translated (transliterated or kept as is).

I obviously can't speak for those who don't ;) But apparently some want to keep their language clear from anglicisms (and sometimes other influences as well..) and translate everything they can find a word for. And i have an impression that there's a bias in that these people are doing more translations.

So in the end, any translation decision can make some people unhappy.

As for specifically "merger", even when i try to ignore my "non-translation" bias, i still don't see much point in hurriedly localizing word that has no translation tradition. 0net dev community seems to be quite small and non-english dev communities even smaller if exist at all. Arguably, merger feature is something that non-developers should also be aware of, but localized word in the interface is not going to make that happen.

If i would be making decision for localization into a language i don't know, i would probably ask translators to give usage examples of their translations. If there are none, i'd probably wait until community actually starts using some word.

>But then why not simply use tor and not decentralization?

It's really only about convenience. We could just as well use ssh to talk to friends, but reaching random audience usually requires using random protocols. Asking a few people to host your 0net site is a bit easier than finding a truly reliable hosting reliably reachable from repressive region.

If you're a "power user", you don't exactly "need" 0net to make your message "visible" and even "permanent". There are a bunch of alternatives to consider. But for some it will be the easiest way to leave a message without worrying too much about visibility and anonymity (of course, you *should* worry about anonymity if it's a concern to you, but many people are not tech-savvy enough to do that).

Also you have to consider that there are much more "oppressive regimes" on the internets than what people usually consider on clearnet. And then there are a lot of people who would rather use proper network regardless of whether it is feasible that their message will be censored by the gov or not.

> [homulilly](#comment_30_1JXekkVYJNdozXPFXZEA1AJXKjkWyFciTD): Applying Game Theory to human interaction is not very sensible. The idea of using Game Theory in a sociopolitical context was developed by John Nash while he was suffering from severe paranoid Schizophrenia and he disavowed it after recovering. He later died in a car crash due to not wearing a seatbelt so all in all, not a guy I would suggest modeling your life or world views after even if he was a genius when it came to mathematics.

Regardless of the truthfullness of conclusions/your initial statement, your argument is somewhat fallacious. It might be considered sound (though not necessarily true) that "modeling your life or world views after" "certain person who died due to not wearing seatbelt", but you also imply (without any sound proofs) that everybody who applies "game theory to human interaction" is following John Nash. While it may be vacuously true from historical point of view, it certainly isn't from the everyday logic (it may also be especially useless if someone would point to most likely existed person who did the similar (not necessarily called the same) thing before Nash). I'm pretty sure that most (but, in any case, at least some) people apply game theory to human interaction without any knowledge of who Nash is or what he thought and how his views developed.

Your sentiment might be somewhat effective towards people who consider "paranoid Schizophrenia Nash" to be god for some reason; it can also be somewhat affecting people who consider Nash to be relevant to the point or just highly authoritative. But there are a lot of people (i wouldn't even start guessing how much at this point) who **don't care about ideas' so-called *initial authors* whatsoever**.

If anything, by providing a fallacious argument to an idea, you're at the same time providing an (also fallacious) counter-argument to it.: How ever stupid the idea of applying game theory to human interaction might be, denying it out only because "some John Nash was suffering and died" is no smarter, to say the least.

>Obviously the primary reason you shouldn't be using Game Theory as a model for human behavior is that it's empirically been proven to be a terrible predictor of human behavior :P

The problem is that it isn't possible to empirically prove anything like that. The closest would be "most people who are using game theory that way fail terribly at it", which does seem to be true. But it doesn't follow that game theory per se is inapplicable.

>The world is too complex and life is too short for one person to understand the totality in human knowledge, that's why experts exist.

So-called "experts" would say opposite opinions, so you'd have an expert-choosing criteria anyway. And gaining that might be no simpler than generic idea criteria.

>In a sense, anyone applying game theory to sociopolitical behavior is following John Nash

Yeah, and in a sense anyone who draw pictures is following Hitler. The problem here is how to define what kind of "in a sense" is relevant and what kind is not. If all you can come up with is "in a sense", it probably isn't relevant.

>Ideas should stand alone and be evaluated by their own merit

>no one should care about an ideas' initial author

Depends on what's the point and who's discussing it. If you're ready to be discussing ideas per se, you don't need additional context for the argument per se. Most people, however, hold some opinions without basing them on any reliable evidence or sound arguments. (This is especially prominent in political "discussions"). In these cases it might be better for a person to consider that if they disagree with someone on one point, they should look deeper into those points that they do agree (kinda cliche situation is when nationalists have friends from the "wrong" nationality, but are very reluctant to put their basic dogmas to doubt).

So, essentially, author's biography cannot be argument for or against generic idea, but it can be an argument to further investigate opposing opinion.

It should be also noted, though, that further investigation shouldn't be limited to idea at hand. Returning to initial game theory / John Nash example, it might be also useful to contemplate whether the aforementioned facts of his biography should even be considered as bad.

>Newton got his theory of gravity wrong.

>Neither an appeal to authority (in the case of Newton)

I could be missing something, but didn't you just appeal to authority of modern science in order to show problems of Newton's authority?

Also, i'm not sure "wrong" is correct here anyway. If he considered it "the final truth", he was wrong, but if it was merely a good scientific approximation, then calling it "wrong" is an overstatement.

>Like I said, poor phrasing on my part and I totally agree with you.

Well, i was mostly checking we're on the same page ;) As well as that your position is not misunderstood by those who are likely to be triggered by your formulation..

>Lol, you mean by saying that Newton is wrong, implicitly using modern science as my source for that? Not really? I'm not claiming any authority figure as my source, but rather the discoveries made regarding the validity of relativity since his time. Yes, Newtonian gravity is a decent approximation in most cases, but it's demonstrably inaccurate on a macro scale. That's not an appeal to authority, but a claim based on evidence. I did have to think about it for a second, though, and had a chuckle at the initial appearance of irony :p

Have you personally examined the evidence though?

There is a difference between appealing to single authority figure and appealing to "modern science" authority, yeah. But unless you've actually examined all the evidence (including the evidence that measuring tools are doing what they're supposed to do), it's still appeal to authority in the broad sense.

That's not to say that i think you're supposed to do better in this specific question. I'm not aware of any way of checking every scientific fact that wouldn't involve dying (of old age if nothing else) in the process. But realizing that you have to take chances with anything you consider to be "fact" might help with understanding flat-earthers and other proponents of "alt-science" and typical conspiracy theories.

>Painting existed before the 1900s you doofus.

Interesting, comparing something (even not necessarily anyone in particular) to nazis is really quite consistent in evoking emotional response.

But if you would examine the context more careful, you might notice that existence of painting at any moment of time has nothing to do with my statement. In fact if you would think about it a bit more, you'd probably realize that i was fully aware of the perfectly humdrum fact that certain Adolf didn't invent painting and that it might be just a trap for a knee jerk reaction.

>you are only talking to tor peers

does not seem to be quite correct. I think what happens is that tor nodes can initiate connection with tor-supporting nodes and nodes with open port, while non-tor nodes can't initiate connection to tor-only nodes. As a result, you can "push" updates to non-tor nodes, but can't "serve" the content to them passively.

1545819941_1G2W1r5Eh1M81v8sUanDq2Cj4xnaR.body:
This is probably because 0mail messages are stored as sender's data, not receiver's. Which means that sender is the one who can delete them (also quite annoying, but then it's a general rule of 0net: unless you back up data, it can be deleted)

Essentially, 0mail does not "send" messages. It simply stores all messages, signed with various keys and then you can read messages signed with your public keys. Since all messages are available to everyone (in encrypted form), deleting them would not substantially increase your privacy. If you're afraid someone might eventually crack your key and read them, they can do it with their backup just as well

For  secure private one-to-one communication you should use direct P2P solutions (but then there is a problem of offline messaging)

Giving out keys (rather than adding ones) is generally a dubious idea as it only protects against key/person loss, but only makes more targets to attack. Next, when it comes to consensus-voting key, candidate should be able to respond timely and meaningfully. Otherwise we risk people voting "yes" to keep things going as well as their voting rights; that would undermine the purpose of consensus in the first place

1567212655_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
- data uri can only increase the size of svg (because it uses only part of available characters per byte)
- they are human-unreadable
- svg can be embedded in html directly without mangling it into unreadable mess (arguably, this can make it bigger than data-uri svg, if the latter is compressed, but.. http compression is a thing, too)
- finally, having separate files is much more convenient for understanding how things work and editing

As for using svg vs raster when it's possible, i fully support it (as long as it doesn't break things for users)

> [gitcenter](#comment_855_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): How many RCEs did those projects have?

I'd rather not go into this sideline argument.

I agree that more developers would be better. But what's the way forward? If nofish does not listen to you, it seems the only option is to fork (it doesn't have to be "hard fork", either). I think you're wasting too much energy on trying to convince people "development should be decentralized". If nofish is inattentive towards reasonable PRs, other developers who experience this would likely join you. As long as there's compatibility, users will be able to switch easily if they feel need. And then the plugins already make 0net not fully compatible across users, which means that another variation wouldn't even make much difference

Finally, forking would allow fixing issues like "default sites list" which are unlikely to ever get approved even if nofish manages development better otherwise

(Personally, i don't think much of current 0net code should be kept in the future. I would rewrite most (if not all) of it from scratch, maintaining compatibility via conversion mechanism rather than keeping all the mess internally; unfortunately, i don't have time/energy/motivation to do that alone, and it doesn't seem like there are any other developers interested in doing things the way i think is best. Which is the main reason i'm not even trying to get involved into 0net development)

Network effect. No one posts something everyone would want to consume, no one wants to consume what people want to post. And yes, amount of people who care about p2p/lack of censorship/free speech is beyond statistically noticeable amount. *We* would notice that amount, but one has to be at intersection of "theoretically interested in 0net" and "have heard of it" to actually appear here, which reduces the numbers to about the point we are at now
  
There is also a problem that most people who *would prefer* p2p solutions would only tolerate a very low amount of inconvenience/lack of users/etc. So, if they would all join at the same time, we might've had enough to use network effect to our advantage, but as it is, it works against us..
